13.03.text:
My name is Kerryn Wagg and I
am a conservation technician

16.05.text:
in the paper and textiles conservation
lab at the National Museum of Australia

19.35.text: and I would like to begin today by

21.18.text:
acknowledging the traditional owners
on the land on which we meet.

25.08.text:
Today’s workshop is part of our Door to
Store: Caring for your collection series,

29.28.text:
and during this session
we will be discussing

31.19.text:
and demonstrating some of the principles
of caring for hats and shoes.

35.43.text:
I would like to welcome
everyone here today

37.42.text:
and advise  you that the
program is being recorded

40.11.text:
and your attendance is
considered consent to be recorded.

43.56.text:
So can everyone now please ensure
that your mobile phones

50.09.text:
I would also
like to extend a welcome to

52.13.text:
everyone who is tuning in live
from the Kiama Library today.

55.44.text: Let’s cross to Kiama and to Michelle Hudson,

57.44.text:
the manager of library
services, at Kiama Library,

60.32.text:
who will be facilitating
the program from her end.

68.53.text:
We are here with a small but
very dedicated

71.55.text:
self confessed shoe-aholics
who are really interested

78.57.text:
We look forward to asking you some
questions at the end of the session.

86.39.text: The idea for this session came about because

88.76.text:
our conservation team has recently
been treating and preparing

91.62.text:
a number of wonderful examples
of hats and shoes for our

94.89.text:
Glorious Days: Australia 1913
exhibition, which is currently on

100.44.text:
So I urge everyone here today
to visit the exhibition

103.03.text:
and, for those of you in Kiama, the
exhibition runs until 13 October

107.84.text:
this year so you have plenty of time
to get to Canberra to check it out.

112.69.text:
In addition to treating damage and
preparing objects for display,

117.35.text:
our conservation team also ensures the
preservation of the Museum’s collection

121.67.text:
by implementing preventative
measures relating to maintaining

124.64.text:
suitable environmental conditions for
objects, ensuring good handling practices

129.26.text:
and having the correct types
of physical storage for items.

132.81.text:
Many of the issues
surrounding the preservation

135.53.text:
of our Museum objects are the
same as for your

141.04.text:
I will go over some of the
general preventative principles

143.82.text:
of providing good care for hats
and shoes before handing over to

152.50.text:
and senior paper and textiles
conservator Carmela Mollica

156.74.text:
who will look at some good
techniques for handling and storage.

161.63.text:
Deterioration and damage to hats and
shoes occurs because

165.73.text:
of inherent and external factors. The
inherent factors relate to aspects

169.03.text:
of the physical makeup
of objects which

171.13.text:
causes them to deteriorate, and these
problems can be difficult to deal with.

174.88.text:
External factors that
contribute to deterioration

177.23.text:
and damage are easier
for us to control.

180.04.text:
Something worth thinking
with when it comes to your

182.28.text:
own hats and shoes is whether
these are items you wish to wear

185.79.text:
or whether you are putting them
away to be preserved for the future.

189.35.text:
If you do intend to wear the items, you
need to accept that there

192.25.text: will be some general damage caused through use.

196.06.text: If you wish to preserve the items by putting them away,

198.45.text:
then dark storage is the best
place for shoes and hats,

201.17.text:
and visible and particularly UV light causes
materials to fade and become brittle.

206.08.text:
Shoes and hats generally are
very susceptible to the damage

208.96.text:
caused by light, and this
damage is cumulative and irreversible.

214.69.text:
Storage areas should ideally
have a relative humidity

217.18.text:
of between 45 and 55 per cent.
This is not always easy to attain,

222.41.text:
but you also want to try to
keep the relative humidity stable.

227.07.text:
This is important because the
amount of moisture in the air

230.59.text:
can cause materials in hats and shoes
to swell and contract,

234.80.text:
and this leads to distortion of items.
The distortion can be accentuated

238.62.text:
when there are numerous different
types of materials present

241.53.text:
because these will be
affected at different rates.

244.76.text:
So if possible, there should be
no dramatic or frequent

251.95.text:
as temperature has a direct
relationship

253.94.text:
with relative humidity
and, generally speaking,

256.93.text:
conditions that are comfortable for
humans are good for hats and shoes.

261.65.text:
When your hats and shoes are
affected by pests   and mould,

264.43.text:
this tends to also be related to
poor environmental conditions,

267.43.text:
so look for what the cause of
these outbreaks is.

270.43.text:
Keep your storage areas clean, and check
your shoes and hats regularly

274.33.text:
so that any mould, rodent or insect
damage can be detected early.

279.60.text:
When items do sustain this type
of damage, it is probably best

282.73.text:
to consult a conservator. You can find a
conservator in your area by visiting

287.83.text:
Australian Institute for the
Conservation of Cultural Materials

296.77.text:
The conditions in the
centre of your house

298.62.text:
will generally be the best and most
stable place to store your items.

302.68.text:
Try to avoid places against
external walls, in roof cavities

305.68.text: or under houses and things like that.

308.40.text:
When you handle your
shoes and hats, you should ensure

310.87.text:
that your hands are clean or, if
you prefer, you can wear gloves.

314.57.text:
Close-fitting, powder-free
surgical plastic gloves are good.

318.14.text:
Cotton gloves can be fine for
some things like leather shoes,

322.01.text:
but you do need to be aware
that they can catch on

324.19.text: some of the materials on hats and shoes.

327.74.text:
Always support the hats and
shoes when you are moving them,

330.15.text: particularly if they are old and fragile.

333.38.text:
Storing your shoes and hats in boxes will
protect them from dust and air pollution,

338.06.text:
but the enclosure should be correctly
dimensioned and constructed

344.85.text:
Now I am going to hand
over Carmela and Michelle

349.38.text:
who will demonstrate some
of these types of storage.

354.26.text:
Thanks Kerryn. Like Kerryn said,
there are various techniques

360.51.text:
we do use to look after our hats
and shoes in our collection.

364.21.text:
What we are going to do here
today is touch on

366.82.text:
three main ones that we look at. As
we all know, there is such a variety

370.85.text:
of shoes, boots and hats so
a lot of these techniques

375.35.text:
can be adapted for each
of those different items.

381.88.text: We will talk about soft supports;

384.71.text: we will talk about rigid supports;

386.45.text: and we will talk about boxing.

388.43.text: There are times when we combine

392.62.text: achieve what we want to achieve.

394.41.text:
I will start talking about our soft supports.
When we talk about soft supports,

400.03.text:
it means something that I can actually
compress and mould into an item.

409.57.text: We can use them in the shoes.

412.00.text:
If we have a pair of shoes that
already have a fairly firm toe,

418.53.text:
a soft support is going to be
enough to just help that shape

422.70.text:
and maintain it in storage because we
all know things collapse over time.

426.81.text: And if you're familar with.. ah

430.08.text: You might have a collection of shoes

432.16.text:
that have already compressed.
We want to maintain that.

437.37.text:
The simplest way to
achieve one of those is,

440.52.text:
either a good old pair of socks
that you can buy

445.76.text:
- we usually go for light
colours, as well if possible, and cotton.

451.37.text:
Once we have a pair of socks, we then
fill them up with a dacron wadding.

456.18.text:
Dacron wadding is what you will
find in your doona covers.

461.49.text: A lot of quilters use them.

463.05.text:
We purchase that from your
local haberdashery store.

466.43.text:
But even before you
start your supports, you really

470.53.text: need to look at your item and

472.33.text:
assess its condition, the
materials it’s made out of

478.26.text: and really look at it and see,

480.86.text:
‘Well, if I do put in a soft
support, is that going to achieve

483.98.text:
what I am trying to achieve or am
I going to cause further damage?’

488.28.text:
If you are unsure about
it, it’s probably best

490.72.text:
not to put anything
in there - leave it.

493.98.text:
We do find that a lot of the
older shoes have silk linings that

498.96.text:
have started to disintegrate, so
applying or adding something else

503.69.text:
to it may cause further damage.
Going back to the soft support,

508.15.text:
I will just demonstrate a little,
what we call a sausage.

513.11.text:
That can vary in size: it can be
big flat one or slim one.

517.35.text:
We roll our dacron and make a little
tube out of our smooth fabric.

523.00.text:
That’s another thing when you
look at your socks, make sure

527.38.text:
they are quite smooth. Don’t have
firm ridges on your sock

532.80.text:
because anything that is rigid can
imprint into your item over time,

538.03.text: especially if it’s a silk shoe,  or something like that or even the leather.

542.69.text:
Here we are using what
we call a par silk,

546.32.text:
which is a polyester lining
fabric that dressmakers will use,

551.69.text: and again our haberdashery store is our best friend.

555.25.text:
We find a lot of fabrics from - our
local Spotlight is a good one.

562.25.text:
Whenever we do use
any of the fabrics,

564.24.text:
we need to make sure
we do pre wash them

566.68.text:
just to remove any starches or
impurities that may have impregnated

573.92.text:
into the fabric during
manufacture, because again we

577.35.text:
want to remove any of those
impurities that over time will

584.19.text:
We have filled up this
sausage with Dacron

587.66.text: and we then need to close off the ends.

592.18.text:
The reason being is, we don’t
want any little insects

595.38.text:
sort of crawling into our supports, starting
little nests and causing further damage.

602.01.text:
As Kerryn mentioned, our
pest management side

605.59.text:
of it is a very important thing
that we need to consider.

609.43.text:
In order to very quickly close up the
end, I just fold over the edge and

616.86.text:
run a running stitch with my cotton
and the needle just in and out,

626.63.text:
pulling it through, all the way
around and then just pulling that thread.

630.61.text:
You can see it’s just     filling up
and closing that end off.

635.16.text:
A couple of stitches
to then secure it off,

640.81.text:
and I end up with a
finished edge like that.

644.17.text:
So they're really handy
to be able to squeeze in softly into that.

651.94.text:
From our softer supports, we can
then use in our little bonnets

658.60.text:
or our bigger hats - a
couple of examples here

664.08.text:
with this little
- I'll just pull this little bonnet out–

667.54.text:
you can see we have
made almost like

669.76.text:
a little doona for it inside. One of
the things we want to prevent is

674.77.text:
sharp creases in our textiles,
because over time they will cause

680.36.text:
splitting of the fibres. So by
providing that little bit

683.23.text:
of support we will prevent that.
In this case there is a lovely

687.65.text:
little rosette and we want to
make sure that is sitting

691.93.text:
facing upwards in the box that
we are going to put it into.

695.66.text:
As you can see here, I have managed to
fit four little bonnets in the one box.

702.47.text:
If you have the space then put
them in an individual box

704.89.text:
- and Michelle will talk more
about boxing - but in this case

708.21.text:
we have combined a number of
them and interleaved with again

717.77.text:
One thing we do need to
look at is dye transfer so

721.77.text:
we need make sure there
is some separation there.

727.56.text:
Going on from our soft supports
we can go into our rigid

734.22.text:
supports which are a lot firmer.
They are great for our boots.

738.94.text:
In this case these are quite
firm to start off with,

741.39.text:
but a lot of boots you sit them
up and they will flop over,

744.86.text:
and eventually they will split along
that bent over area.

749.78.text: So we want to provide a firm support in there.

753.72.text:
What we use for the firm supports
is what we call an ether foam.

762.44.text:
The ether foam is quite a
firm polypropylene plastic.

770.02.text:
There are no plasticisers that
can be emitted from this plastic

774.79.text:
and cause discolouration or
degradation of our items.

779.57.text:
It’s quite firm so it’s
not going to compress.

782.95.text:
It’s quite nice - you can
use a carving knife

786.05.text:
or a Stanley knife to shape
whatever shape you want to make,

793.71.text: a little dome for a hat

796.68.text:
or, in this case, our
little shapes for our boots.

805.28.text:
well, once we've got  the shoe, our
little firm inserts don’t bend

811.22.text:
as easily as our foot does,
sometimes we do need to make

814.70.text:
them into two parts. In this case
it has a little foot section

819.91.text:
that feeds into the
bottom part of the boot.

822.72.text:
You can probably
see my little tail on that,

825.95.text:
and that is to assist me when I
want to retrieve it.

829.87.text:
So I am not having to put my hand down
the middle of the boot, I can gently

836.14.text:
pull that up and
retrieve it again.

838.79.text:
Then the centre of it can just sit
in there and retain its shape.

846.28.text:
If you look at the foam, it’s
quite a rough surface.

849.95.text:
We want to achieve a
nice smooth surface so we

853.52.text:
are not catching on
anything inside the item.

856.20.text:
We cover that with
our dacron wadding

860.64.text:
- exactly the same as
what I explained earlier.

867.10.text:
The nice thing about this ether
foam is you don’t have to do

869.78.text:
any stitching, you can just
slit the foam and

873.64.text:
it just pokes into that
groove and retains in there.

881.77.text:
So it just has the one seam and
the rest of it is quite smooth.

885.95.text:
Once we have covered that in the Dacron,
we then cover it in the par silk again.

896.59.text:
over the surface and feeding it back
into that original slit that we've got,

902.06.text: and you have a nice smooth surface.

906.63.text:
Ether foam, pool noodles
- same thing

913.44.text:
so that’s something that we can use.
It’s the same material.

919.18.text:
Obviously it comes into various colours
that we need to be a bit wary about.

923.79.text:
By covering it totally in the
two layers we will prevent

931.74.text:
any transference of
colours, with that.

935.87.text:
We can still achieve
the firmness

940.01.text:
for a support, even with our little
dacron sausage,

946.31.text:
by using archival card and
slipping that inside the cover.

952.87.text:
Say, for example, it’s
not quite the right size,

956.34.text:
that would slip inside and the wadding
would be in the centre,

960.26.text:
the card around it and then the par
silk covering the whole item.

966.16.text: That will create a rigid form for us.

970.63.text:
Archival card is also
a good thing to use.

973.81.text:
Sometimes you only need a little bit of
support around the inside of the hat.

983.74.text:
Kerryn mentioned about archival
materials that they need to be

988.63.text:
acid free and inert materials.
But we do need to make sure that

995.45.text:
we don’t use any staples, any metal fastenings,
when we join or create that shape.

1002.05.text:
So in this case I have just used some cotton
thread and stitched the two together.

1008.01.text:
You can see that it has
joined them together.

1013.73.text: That will sit inside the hat nicely.

1017.13.text:
Just a couple of
examples here using the

1024.30.text:
rigid support and you
can see that sometimes

1026.85.text:
you need to be quite creative for something
like this with a lovely brim on it.

1031.82.text:
We need to support it. Here we have
actually created quite an interesting shape

1044.25.text:
in two bits, a triangular
bit to support the brim of it

1049.17.text: and this is using the rigid system.

1056.31.text:
There are ribbons with the
bonnet that have been rolled,

1059.45.text:
and Michelle will
talk about rolling later.

1064.98.text:
So it has firmly
held its shape, and we are not

1068.85.text:
creating any extra creases
in that little bonnet.

1072.36.text:
Then we have this other little cap here.
Before I lift it, you can see that

1078.18.text: it actually sits above the surface.

1081.61.text:
Again, lifting things off the
surface so that, when we

1085.17.text:
go to handle these items, we are
not touching the edge

1089.84.text:
of the hat, it’s actually the support
that we are holding, I suppose.

1099.19.text:
In this case we have a
combination of two,

1118.92.text:
we have created little sausages inside
that sit there and hold their shape.

1134.14.text:
Going across to these little shoes here,
little triangular shapes are enough

1143.62.text: that little shoe tip just there.

1149.99.text: We don’t want to make the forms

1154.07.text:
and push them too
hard in the shoe.

1157.23.text:
It needs to provide the support
but be not crammed in there

1161.25.text:
so that you are causing
further damage to it.

1167.90.text:
Sometimes you may want to consider making
little bags for individual shoes or boots.

1175.88.text:
Just simple, using the par silk fabric to
make a little draw string bag,

1182.13.text:
which is nice to store them
in to protect them from dust

1193.27.text:
I have a hat stand here. Some
people like to display hats.

1196.78.text:
Rather than sitting a hat straight
onto the spike of the hat stand

1204.18.text:
- if it’s your general everyday sun
hat that you are going to be wearing,

1207.92.text:
that’s not a problem, but if
it is something of significance

1210.88.text:
that you want
to look after,

1213.50.text:
a rigid support like this
with a hole in the end

1218.09.text:
that sits inside
your hat and then

1225.23.text:
pokes into the spoke
of the hat stand.

1228.02.text: And you can create quite a nice

1232.88.text:
in mind all your parameters
- your light levels and dust

1246.05.text: I don’t know what else to say.

1253.72.text:
like I said, there
is such a variety

1255.41.text: of items out there that you

1257.40.text:
just bring in your creativity,
keeping in mind your creases

1261.42.text:
when assessing your object:
can I put in something soft and

1266.63.text:
not cause any further damage; or
yes, I do need to provide support

1272.34.text:
that needs to be a bit
rigid, don’t cram it in there.

1278.47.text:
I think a lot of damage does
occur with incorrect

1282.02.text: handling of your item. So we look at ...

1285.84.text:
We use our eyes a lot and look
at the item in detail before

1290.09.text: we even attempt any of these techniques.

1294.09.text:
I will hand you over
to Michelle who will

1296.64.text:
talk about ... once we assess all
of this and work out our system

1302.38.text:
of padding we then look at boxing,
which is very important as well.

1308.96.text:
I will talk generally
about the two main types

1312.00.text:
of storage boxes that
we use in the Museum first of all,

1315.20.text:
and then I will take you through
a few examples to give you

1317.72.text:
some specific ideas about how you
can store components of your

1322.09.text:
hats and shoes. We use archival
corrugated board for our boxes,

1328.39.text:
which we have in both ready
made sizes and also we can make

1333.05.text:
these to a custom size for our
hats and shoes.

1336.62.text:
The benefit of the corrugated archival
board is that, as well as protecting

1343.12.text:
your object from dust and light,
it also reduces the rate

1349.64.text:
of exchange in
temperature and humidity

1352.68.text:
for your object, particularly
if you have other buffering

1355.30.text:
materials inside, which helps keep your
object in a more stable environment.

1360.51.text:
They can also be used inside a
larger box, so you can have

1365.15.text:
a number of objects together in
a box and have them separated.

1370.85.text:
One of the considerations
with the corrugated board is

1375.15.text:
that, because it is corrugated,
it does leave a nice little space

1379.63.text:
for insects to get into
the warmth of the box.

1382.43.text:
In the Museum we have a preventive
conservation officer who obviously

1386.80.text:
is monitoring our collection; but
at home you can overcome this by

1390.37.text:
using archival tape along the
edges of your box to prevent

1393.76.text:
insects making a home in there.
The other type of box that we use

1398.38.text:
is polypropylene and these are
a ready made size that we use.

1405.59.text:
The disadvantage with them is
that they can create

1411.20.text:
a micro-climate inside.
While they obviously

1413.73.text:
keep moisture out, if you have
them in a situation where

1417.83.text:
you have a sudden change in
high humidity, you can cause

1421.70.text:
condensation inside that
box which can then lead

1424.61.text:
to mould or mildew
on your objects.

1426.86.text:
So you possibly need more buffering
material inside those boxes.

1432.97.text:
Obviously when you
have a cardboard box,

1436.33.text:
you want to put it in a situation
in your house

1437.96.text:
where it is not going to
have any direct moisture.

1440.87.text:
You need to be careful
about placing it, say,

1443.50.text:
in the floor of a
cupboard where you might

1448.09.text:
You also want to make sure
they are not stored near

1451.26.text:
a hot water system or where you
possibly may have

1454.31.text:
leaks through the roof or from leaky pipes.
It’s important to make sure

1458.68.text:
that you monitor your storage frequently,
keep an eye on that, and obviously

1464.50.text:
move objects to a better place in
the house if that’s happening.

1468.73.text:
Inside the box, once we
have the dimensions which

1473.43.text:
are best suited to our object,
we can then use the internal

1479.40.text:
supports that Carmela has spoken
about, especially if you have

1485.87.text:
For example, with these
hats, the supports

1488.89.text:
are actually connected
to the base which then can be

1494.44.text:
lifted into your box, which means the
objects are separated from each other.

1499.74.text:
If you have a special
significant object,

1503.84.text:
it means you can view those
objects or that you can have

1507.19.text:
your family around to view those objects
and really reduce the amount of

1510.11.text:
handling of those. This is
another example where we have a

1516.03.text:
drop down side, we have some
cotton tape threaded to a hole

1520.85.text:
through the side and we have a
support, which is again connected

1525.63.text:
to a tray that can be lifted out,
and that can easily be viewed

1535.24.text:
The other consideration
when you are storing

1538.99.text: objects together is to try to put

1544.52.text:
For example, you wouldn’t
put a military helmet

1548.42.text:
with a christening bonnet, because
you would have the danger

1551.05.text:
of one falling on top of
another and crushing it.

1553.59.text:
It’s a good idea to have like
objects together in a box.

1559.30.text:
You would keep
pairs of shoes together in a box.

1561.62.text: And I will show you this example,

1563.56.text: this is a pair of flat shoes which

1573.42.text:
What we have done here is
used the corrugated card

1576.98.text:
to cut a template out,
which sits inside the box

1579.85.text:
and prevents those objects
moving around,

1583.26.text: and then they are tied in place.

1585.78.text:
We also have a photo of
that object on the lid.

1589.31.text:
It’s a good idea if you
have multiple boxes to have

1593.81.text:
labelling and photos so that you
know exactly what is in those boxes

1598.24.text:
without having to rummage
through them all the time.

1602.18.text:
Another consideration is dye transfer.
If you have coloured flowers or

1606.98.text: coloured feathers, it’s a good idea

1611.71.text:
from perhaps light coloured
objects so you don’t have any

1615.48.text:
dye transfer transferring. You
need adequate space inside your

1619.48.text:
box so that the decorative
aspects of your object do not

1626.63.text: crushed against the side of the box.

1628.54.text:
This one is a good example of that
where it has ribbons that we have

1634.01.text:
actually rolled onto cardboard
rolls that have been covered

1639.37.text:
in tissue, which reduces
the amount of space

1643.10.text:
that we need for the boxing and
also keeps the ribbons flat.

1647.83.text:
So they are held there in
a very good situation.

1653.40.text:
We have plenty of room around
our fabric flowers here so that

1657.45.text:
they are not being crushed. Then
our solid support underneath

1660.84.text:
is connected again to
the bottom of the box.

1665.19.text:
Here we have an
example where we have multiple

1671.71.text:
We actually have a lift-out
section at the bottom.

1674.67.text:
We have a tray with
handles

1677.28.text:
which fits inside this box
where we have other components

1681.80.text: that are related to this object as well.

1686.80.text:
With this one you can
see it’s a matter of really

1689.56.text:
having a look at what types of
materials your object is made from

1693.72.text:
to decide what supports are
here going to be best.

1696.36.text:
Here we have a very soft
dacron sausage roll,

1702.82.text:
the daisies on the
back of these shoes.

1706.25.text:
It’s a matter of analysing
your object,

1710.35.text:
working out where it needs
the best kind of support,

1713.52.text:
And you can fit out your boxes
with separate components,

1718.33.text:
separate compartments, and
again you can use trays

1723.03.text:
or smaller boxes inside
to separate your objects.

1727.08.text:
In terms of your buffering
material, archival tissue

1731.71.text:
or soft supports are what we would
generally use at the Museum.

1735.48.text:
For long term storage,
soft supports

1739.07.text:
in fabrics that are inert and are not going
to cause any damage

1743.25.text:
by off gas into our objects
are our preference.

1746.64.text:
So we would use again
the par silk sausages,

1754.69.text:
of a box with a layer
of dacron underneath.

1758.24.text:
Something very simple that
you can incorporate into

1762.15.text:
perhaps your the storage of
your shoes in a shoe box

1765.13.text:
is a layer of dacron with the
par silk covering over the top

1769.27.text:
or, you can seperate again,
as Carmela mentioned,

1773.06.text:
seperating your objects
separately into  bags.

1777.07.text:
So I think that has
really covered

1779.28.text: most of the aspects of the boxing.

1793.10.text:
plastic tubs that you  can purchase,  food
containers like Tupperware

1798.76.text:
- I won’t say the $2 containers
that you can also buy to store food in

1803.97.text:
as a temporary measure - but your
long term storage containers,

1810.82.text:
but keeping in mind like
Michelle was saying

1812.78.text:
about the buffering
and things like that.

1815.62.text:
With your shoeboxes, if you still want
to retain and store your shoes in

1820.99.text:
your shoe boxes, obviously they
are not archival so we need to

1824.55.text:
provide that layer, that interleaving
layer like Michelle mentioned

1829.47.text:
polyethylene sheeting is something
that you can line, but then always use

1838.21.text:
your fabric layer between
your object and the plastic.

1845.21.text:
So theres, other general items out
there that you can use to create

1852.09.text:
the same system as what we are
looking at with the boxes that

1863.80.text:
So now I think we have time
for questions.

1865.79.text:
We are going to have questions
from our Visions audience first

1868.84.text:
and then we will cross
to Kiama for questions.

1870.94.text:
Please wait until a microphone
comes around to ask your question,

1874.29.text:
and you can say your name, if you
like, before your question as well.

1896.22.text:
Thank you, that was really
wonderful and so interesting.

1898.83.text:
I have a million questions
but I will just ask one.

1901.61.text:
Once upon a time people
used to wrap these items

1905.99.text:
in tissue paper, but there
is not a skerrick there.

1908.65.text: Is there a reason for that?

1912.39.text:
There is nothing wrong with
using acid-free tissue paper.

1916.94.text:
I suppose we are trying to move away from it in
terms of long term storage

1922.94.text:
for a number of reasons: one is you
don’t get that nice smooth surface

1929.79.text:
necessarily; over time
it does compress so you are

1933.75.text:
having to revisit
your item again

1936.77.text:
to create that shape that
you're wanting to create and

1943.31.text:
to keep the shape of the object, whether
it’s a shoe, hat or anything else.

1947.83.text:
Also t here is also a possibility of insects
harbouring within the tissue.

1955.98.text:
Silverfish insects do
like to eat tissue.

1960.83.text:
They don’t necessarily like
to eat polyester material.

1965.26.text: There is nothing wrong with acid free tissue.

1969.74.text:
I suppose if you are looking at long
term and that sort of prevention, where

1975.34.text:
we are moving more towards these other
materials to create that support.

1983.62.text:
I was just wondering: what happens
when you have a longer gown

1988.61.text:
that might need to be folded multiple
times - how would you deal with that?

1995.10.text:
And also a second question:
where do you source

1997.96.text:
the archival cardboard
boxes and things from?

2005.43.text: Do you want to answer that one?

2006.54.text: Yes, I can answer that one.

2007.97.text:
If you have a large textile
object, you can actually purchase

2015.37.text:
boxes which are for textiles
storage specifically.

2021.06.text:
If you have a very long train,
veil or long christening gown,

2027.57.text:
it’s preferable if you can support
the whole object flat in a box.

2034.19.text: But if you a bit limited with space,

2037.07.text:
you can again use the
par silk dacron sausages

2042.38.text:
as a roll to carefully wrap your
object, and again you would be

2049.11.text:
interleaving that with the par
silk to prevent layers contacting.

2057.20.text:
The main thing you want to do
is really, prevent any definite creases

2062.08.text:
from forming in your textile
because, if you are putting it away

2064.27.text:
for long term storage,
those fibres can eventually

2068.53.text:
if they are breaking down, cause
splits in your object.

2073.56.text:
The other thing you can do, too, is
make soft doonas to fit inside

2078.45.text:
your object as long as it is not
going to cause any compression

2084.91.text:
In terms of the boxes, they can be
sourced through archival suppliers.

2090.05.text:
If you just do a web search
for archival suppliers

2093.72.text:
there are quite a number online
that you can purchase from.

2104.82.text:
Thank you for your
interesting lecture.

2109.26.text:
I notice that with the ribbon
you roll that in around a core,

2117.26.text:
but what do you do with long
leather straps?

2121.25.text:
How do you conserve the leather that
might be a strap with a shoe

2126.90.text:
that is maybe half a metre
long or something like that?

2133.08.text:
What process would
you use for that?

2136.35.text: The example I have given here

2138.72.text:
you would really only use for
a flat single-layer ribbon.

2142.09.text:
If you have a ribbon on the edge
of a bonnet or a shoe strap

2149.45.text:
that is multiple layers, you really
don’t want to wind that tightly,

2154.23.text:
you would want that to be loose, if you
can, just very loosely around the outside.

2161.32.text:
If you have your shoes
say in the centre of

2163.07.text:
the box and have them very loosely
around the outside because

2168.97.text:
if you are storing something in the long
term you don’t want to have that memory

2172.88.text:
of them being tightly rolled,
which would then cause another issue.

2185.82.text:
I had another question about
cleaning the objects.

2188.85.text:
What do you do to clean them
before you put them away?

2193.17.text:
Ah yes, I didn’t sort of run
through that but I can run through

2197.69.text:
briefly what our process
would be at the Museum.

2201.27.text:
It’s ideal to store your
objects clean because,

2205.14.text:
if you are putting them away
dirty, they can attract insects

2209.30.text:
particularly if they have food
stains and that type of thing.

2213.59.text: But very generally, we would be

2216.01.text:
removing dust from the surface
by a very low suction vacuum.

2220.07.text:
We have a special set of tools that
we would use just at a raking angle

2226.47.text:
and sometimes through a screen
to reduce the dust on an object

2229.65.text:
before we put it away,
particularly if you have an object

2233.86.text:
with a pile - say velvet,
fur or that type of thing

2236.83.text:
- you want to make sure all of the
dust is removed from that before

2240.69.text:
it goes into storage. Does that
answer your question?

2247.92.text:
I have a beaded christening
gown [off mic].

2254.41.text: Sorry it's a beaded christening gown?

2257.32.text:
Yes, again a very low suction
vacuum, and obviously

2263.62.text:
you are not going to be vacuuming
straight onto your object.

2266.80.text:
It needs to be at a raking angle and
a very low suction.

2270.88.text:
The screen is ideal for beaded objects,
because you are not going to

2276.35.text:
inadvertently suck up any of your
beads if they happen to be loose.

2281.78.text: Or very soft brush is good as well

2284.83.text:
for the beaded areas
where you can gently

2287.23.text:
brush those areas to
remove any loose dust.

2291.65.text:
But certainly assess the
object to determine how fragile

2295.32.text: is the silk and the beads.

2298.63.text:
We would normally need
to do that assessment

2302.17.text:
before we go to whatever
treatment we look at.

2305.19.text:
If it’s something of concern, you may need
to contact someone to look at it closer.

2313.33.text:
If you can see any loose fibres or
beads, it’s probably a good idea

2318.42.text:
to have a conservator look
at cleaning that for you.

2324.04.text:
Was there a list of conservators
that you could contact?

2328.81.text:
So if you visit the AICCM website
and if you just do a search for

2333.02.text:
AICCM it will come up, there is a
link to conservators in your area.

2339.10.text:
All of the conservators on that
website are good people to contact.

2348.51.text:
Okay, so that's wonderful, we will cross to
Kiama now and take questions

2355.83.text:
Hi, We really enjoyed your
presentation at Kiama.

2359.09.text:
We got some fabulous hints
with what we can do.

2363.46.text:
One of my questions would be: I
have an old top hat displayed

2368.31.text:
on a wooden hat stand and
it’s quite a solid hat stand.

2372.85.text: Would there be any problems with that situation?

2376.51.text:
Would there be any transfer from
the wood across to the hat?

2383.69.text:
Depending on the wood
that’s been used for the

2386.64.text:
hat stand, there could possibly
be acidity being transferred.

2392.88.text:
Normally a top hat may have a silk
lining so that may react with the silk.

2399.43.text:
So, it might be an idea to just
provide a barrier,

2405.50.text:
whether it's a par silk barrier,
that would help reduce any of that.

2416.66.text: Thank you, that sounds like a good idea.

2421.89.text: That’s all the questions from Kiama.

2426.61.text:
We will take more questions
from Visions, if there are any.

2431.37.text:
This question might be out of the scope
of this discussion about shoes and hats.

2436.28.text:
But in terms of accessories,
things like parasols

2442.47.text:
or fans that might be
made of fabric feathers,

2447.69.text:
delicate things, is that out of the scope
of this particular discussion in terms

2454.90.text:
of storage for those
kinds of objects?

2459.68.text:
You do have shoes that
have a combination of  materials;

2463.92.text:
silk, beaded, hats with feathers,
so it’s not out of scope.

2473.21.text:
I suppose, the principles are the same, whether it’s
a shoe, a hat or a parasol.

2478.04.text:
So similar techniques for your
packing, assessing the object

2483.19.text:
before actually handling it, boxing
it so you are supporting all areas.

2490.49.text:
With a fan, if it’s able to be opened
out, obviously it doesn’t sit flat

2497.44.text:
so you will need to support the
area that is slightly raised.

2501.81.text:
With your parasol. Again  we normally
like to store them upside down

2510.19.text:
so that the weight of
it, but it does need to

2516.23.text:
have a special support
to support the handle.

2520.15.text:
I mean I don’t know what sort of
a handle it has, whether

2522.94.text:
it’s a carriage parasol or
a straight handle on it.

2530.10.text:
Sometimes you can store them upside down
but you need to assess the item.

2535.60.text:
You can make a little cover for
them like that where, if you are

2541.74.text:
storing it upside down, the cover
actually supports the parasol.

2549.37.text:
So there is a number of ways. A
lot of the techniques that we

2553.95.text:
have talked about here can
be adapted to those objects.

2564.98.text:
My voice is probably
loud enough without it.

2567.32.text:
I am assuming that a
normal cardboard box

2569.41.text:
is not acid free and even
with a par silk lining or

2574.13.text: good buffering this is not a good idea?

2578.60.text:
Like a ordinary box, not just a shoe box but
ordinary brown, cardboard, corrugated boxes

2586.27.text: I presume have acid in them.

2588.44.text:
It wouldn’t necessarily be acid free.
We were talking about providing a

2592.66.text:
barrier, and that can be through
using your polyethylene sheeting

2597.49.text:
as your initial layer and then using your
fabric as your contact with your object.

2605.53.text:
So you could use a plain
box as long as you had

2608.66.text:
the barrier and sufficient
buffering in par silk?

2611.54.text:
Yes. A lot of your oven
bags are suitable for

2618.70.text:
lining and providing
that barrier as well.

2630.40.text:
Okay, well thank you everyone and thank you
for your participation, Kiama.

2635.01.text:
I would like to urge
everyone to go and

2638.25.text:
check out our Glorious Days:
Australia 1913 exhibition and

2642.61.text:
thank you for coming along to
our workshop today.
